Binary Operations

Addition & Subtraction

Here the inputs are actually unsigned, so we need 5 bits to represent the output (which can range from -15 to +15). Normally, however, the inputs would also be signed, and so what above appears as 11 - 13 would actually be (-5) - (-3), which is still -5 + 3 = -2. Computations like 6 - (-4) would give -6 instead of +10, but this is exactly the same overflow problem as with the signed addition 6 + 4.

Multiplication

There's a lot going on here, but don't panic! A detailed explanation follows, but see if you can figure out what's going on by watching it. Click the 6 bits just above the adder to set the first number, and the 6 bits to their right for the second one. The giant circle is the power button. Try not to mess with the circuit when it's on!

Oh, and one more thing: The clock with lots of circles (14, to be exact) controls the answer at the bottom. If you wait too long, it will cycle again and erase the answer! You can turn the power off to prevent this.
